definition: enclosing frame made of bamboo, wire etc/cage/basket/steamer basket/to cover/to cage/to embrace/to manipulate through trickery

sentences.english: He had thought that being locked into a cage would send him mad.
sentences.chinese: 他曾以为一经关入樊笼，自己一定会发疯的。

sentences.english: I remember James saying something about people who end their lives in caves.
sentences.chinese: 曾记得詹姆斯说过那些死在樊笼里的人们。

sentences.english: Ah, it must have escaped from its cage. It was a free bird!
sentences.chinese: 啊，这是一只跳出樊笼自由的鸟儿。

sentences.english: Storms break through the night cage to welcome the brilliant tomorrow.
sentences.chinese: 暴风雨冲破夜的樊笼，迎接灿烂的明天。

sentences.english: Freedom is the key to open all cages.
sentences.chinese: 自由是打开一切樊笼的钥匙。

sentences.english: They're never been allowed to love in this cured cage.
sentences.chinese: 她们从未被容许在这个罪过的樊笼里相爱。

sentences.english: He had won his first release from the fences of home.
sentences.chinese: 他第一次成功地脱出家庭的樊笼。

sentences.english: To some power is like a trapped animal trying to get out of a cage.
sentences.chinese: 对某些人来说，力量像是要冲出樊笼的困兽。

sentences.english: They're never been allowed to love in this cursed cage.
sentences.chinese: 她们从未被容许在这个罪过的樊笼里相爱。

definition: cage/trap (e.g. basket, pit or snare for catching animals)/fig. bonds (of wrong ideas)/shackles (of past misconceptions)/to trap/to shackle
lit. fettered by fame and locked up by riches (idiom); tied down by reputation and wealth/the victim of one's own success
lit. to be confined within a circle drawn on the ground (idiom)/fig. to confine oneself to a restricted range of activities
mundane world (in religious context)/this mortal coil
lit. sea of bitterness/abyss of worldly suffering (Buddhist term)/depths of misery
to spread one's wings and soar (idiom)/to develop one's abilities freely
